While that is an illustration stating the postulate of time dilation... the theory isn't "illustrated" ... it's just stated as correct.

Meanwhile time dilation is, and always has been wrong.  Yes, there are effects on matter at that speed, such as unstable atoms taking longer to decay.  No, that is not because they decay at a constant rate of time more accurate than time itself.  The length of the video doesn't change because of an optical illusion because of the time it takes for light to hit us.

This would be like suggesting the doppler effect of sound changing pitch from a passing train is a sign of time dilation because of the auditory illusion.  A change in perception isn't necessarily a change in the fabric of something that doesn't exist.  Time.  Time does not exist, noobs.   It has no beginning, no end, it can not be changed because it's an abstract concept to describe matter... not a "thing" in and of itself.  Otherwise, there would be a universal frame of reference.

For those of you confused about the concept of time dilation, maybe I can help clear it up with a bit of a thought experiment.

Say I were to build a Giant flashlight in the middle of space, and set it so that it would emit a beam of light every ten minutes.

I then get into my spaceship and travel away from it so that the time it takes for light to overtake me is about 20 minutes. Meaning I'm traveling at such a speed away from it, that light takes twice the time to reach me (Seeing as I can't move faster than light, it will EVENTUALLY overtake me.) I do this until I see 5 flashes of light. So at this point I have traveled how ever far it has taken me to travel at such a speed, such that I saw 5 flashes at twenty minute intervals. So at this point it has been 100 minutes. (5x20=100)

At the fifth flash I then turn around immediately (Let's pretend for sake of argument I have infinite velocity, as that's the only way I could turn around immediately at that speed) and fly back toward my giant flashlight. Does it then make sense since light took twice as long to reach me flying away from it, that it should take half as long to reach me flying toward it? This would mean I would see a flash of light every 5 minutes. ) Than traveling the same amount of time seeing the flashes of light every five minutes, that would mean in my 100 minute drive, I would see 20 flashes of light, correct?

But wait a minute... If I traveled only 200 minutes in this round trip, than how could I have see 25 flashes of light? (5 on the outgoing, 20 on the incoming). I programmed that flashlight to flash every 10 minutes, meaning that the 25 times it took to flash is 250 minutes from the perspective of the giant flashlight. The only possible explanation is that while approaching the speed of light, time must have slowed down for me, from the perspective of an outsider, so that my 200 minutes is to the giant flashlight 250.

Say I took this to another extreme, an decided to fly away from it so that light would only over take me every 100 minutes. I were to then turn around immediately, and travel the same speed back, meaning I would see a flash of light every minute. In this example my 200 minute journey, I have seen 101 flashes of light. That would mean from the perspective of the giant flashlight 1010 minutes have passed!

Which to me is a lot of lost time.

For the people who don't get it, here's a quick explanation. When you're dealing with speeds close to the speed of light, relativity comes into play and you get time dilation- time appears to run slower on a moving clock. Therefore the 5 seconds for the moving computer would seem like 10 seconds to you. The factor by which time is dilated is called the Lorentz factor, and is calculated as 1/sqrt(1-((v^2)/(c^2)). Putting in v as 0.87c (87% the speed of light), you get a factor of 2. Because this video is 5 seconds long, if the computer was moving at 0.87c relative to you it would appear 5x2=10 seconds long. Hope that helps :)
